The leading features in the character of
a good woman, are mildness, complaisance,
and equaninity of temper The man, II he
be a providcnt and worthy husband, is i'm
nersed IN Thousand cares. His mind is
agitated, his memory loaded, and his body
fatiguet,. He retircs from the hustle of the
world, chasrincd, perhaps, by disappoiht-
ment, angry at indolcnt or perhdous peo.
pie, and terrified lest his unavoidable con-
nexons with such people, should make him
appear periidious himself. Is this the time
for the wife Of his bosom, his dearest and
most intimate friend, to add to his vcXations,
to increase the fever of an oyerburthened
mind by contentious tongue, or discon-
tented brow? Business, in its most prosper
Gus state, is full of anxiety, labor and tur-
mol. o, how dear to the memory Ct man
is the wife who clothes her tace in smiles,
who uses gentle expressions, and who IN 4krs
her lap soft to receive and hush his Cares to
rest. There is not in nature SO fascinating
an object. as . faithful! tender and affections
ate wife.

REFLECTIONS ON THE MARRIED STATE.


BIZ a MmYied Man.

sweeps every thing along its course, and one
can scarcely get to its waters with any Safe
ty, till it enters the Mendoza plains thirteen
miles below.


In passing the first ladera, we were great
ly alarmed for short time, by circum-
stance which grew out of carelessness.-
Not sending one forward on foot, as we
ought, to see if the way was clear, six of us
advanced SO far, that we could not return,
when we saw, entering the west end of the
ladera, drove of mules, which must soon
meet US. What was to be done For eli
ther party to return, was impossible; to pass
each other no less so. would almost have
sacrificed limb to have been free from the
danger which threatened. As good Provi-
dence ordained it, however, our guide recol-
lectetl that, in the centre of the ladera, then
out of sight, there was a small ravine. or
break in the mountain, where brook de-
scendetl, and where, if we could reach be-
fore the other loose mules met US, we could
probably halt in safety. We reached the
wished-for spot, and crowded our six mules
into a small excavation, which a cascade.
when the brook was high, had made, and
here waited till 800 mules and four men had
passed We then came out of our den,
passed the other part of the ladera, and SO
reached in safety, another wide and good
road.


Just before night we passed the second
ladera, called, Laderas de Ia .racas, the
worst Of them all, but which, with caution,
we passed in perfect safety,-Over this,
ventured to walk and let the mule follow,
but would not again. Ones head is liable
to swim, and then his feet to stumble,
whereas mules head, in such places, is al
WAYS clear, and his feet secure.


The sagacity Of this animal in travelling
over those rough and dangerous roads is tru-
ly remarkable. When he steps on a stone
which rolls or finds his feet likely to give
way, instead of springing to recover himself.
like the horse, he lifts his feet, and places
them again, with increased slowness and eau
tiun, until the danger is passed. When car
ryng baggage, he soon learns to keep at such
distance from loaded mules and other objects
which he may meet, as that his cargo sell
dom strikes any thing around him. In cross
ing these narrow laderas, | observed that
the older baggage mules, to avoid contact
with the mountains above, would walk all
most to the extreme lower edge of the path.
| This caution of course arises not from any
design to preserve the load in charge, but
to save themselves from the severe jar,
which every such contact gives them.
In the worst and most dangerous places
they are perfectly composed, and, if let a.
lone and suffered to pick their own way,
will carry you through them in safety, but,
as the peones say, "it is dangerous to force
one o. those animals, where he, on mature
delioeration, thinks it not best to CO."

81 drcam'd dream that ] had flung a cham
OF roses around l.oye-I woke and found
had ciain'd Sorrow"


have caught the last wave Of his snow-whitc


plume!


How f,st to night closes the evening gloom--
lb,ve heard the last sound of his horsc's feet
On wndi once more the echo repeat!
; shoukl no, weep thus, if thou vert gone
Away 10 tic battle, as oft thou hast done;
Or il wept, my tears would be
But voiceess prisons for thee.
Thou vert wont TO palt--rny scarf on thine


arm.


Afy last kiss laid on thy lips like a charm
could play and believe that Thy maiden's pray'r
Would be wtl. thee il b@ttie. and guard thee


there.


But now thou a,t gone 10 The festival.
To the crowded city, the lighted hall:
In tho courtly beau,l's shining bower,
Little thou'lt think Of thine own wild flower.
Thou wilt Join in the midnight saraband,
With thy graceful smile and thy Whisper bland;
And to many another thou wilt be,
All thou once wert TO only me.
Ymirht haze known what would be my share
Silent suffering, and secret care:
Imght haze flown my wonan's part
faded cheek, and rifed heart.
Often Tread in the minstreltale
How bright eyes grow dim, and rcd lips pale;
Ofthe tears that wall the fond maiden's lot,
But loved thee, and all but my love forgot.
And must this be, oh, heart of mine!
Why art thou not too proud to pine!
Again will wrcathe my raven hair
With the wild rose flowers it was wont to wear.
Again will enter my r;l4her's hall;
Again be the gaycst and gladest of all:
Like the falcon, that soars at her highest bound,
Though her bosom bears its red dea.h-wound.
But what boots it to teach my heart task
So vain, as weeping behind mask;
Broken, with only ruins to hide,
Little it rocks of the show of pride.
viii a smile bring back to my lip its red,
Orthe azure light from my blue eyes fed,
Eflace from the faded brow and cheek
The tale that tells my heart must break.
No! I will away to my solitude,
And hang my head in my darkest moodi
Passing away with silent sigh,
Unknown, unwept, and thus will die!
FAREWELL FAREWELL have but one prayer,
That no thought may haunt thee ofrny despair;
Be nv memory to thee pleasant thing,
An odour that came and passed with thy spring.
Forget mel would not have thee know
of the youth and bloom thy falseness laid low;
That the green grass grows, the Expresses wave
And the deatl-stone lies OH thy once loves grave

BY c. W. THOMPSON.
come, come from the icy seas,

THE ADVENT OF WINTER.

There was poor but very honest, con-
tented, and merry kind of a man, in the vii
lage of rilleda, who happened to be giving
christening treat, for about the eighth
time to some OF his neighbours. DESTROYS
of showing all respect to the party OF chris
tening he set before them the best wine he
possessed. which being quick dispatched,
his guests seemed to be looking for little
more. Go them said the father to the eld-
est daughter, a young girl about sixteen
years old, 'go and bring us some better
wine from the cellar From what cellar.
father p enquired his daughter What cell
lar, child replied the father, merely IN
Jest; why, the great wine cellar belonging
to the Knights upon the kytf Hausen.'
With perfect simplicity the young maiden
took frkin in her hand and proceeded to-
wards the mountain. About middle way,
seated in an old deserted path leading down,
towards the spot, she found an aged house
keeper, dressed III singular quaint fashion.
with large bunch of keys hanging at her
side. The young woman paused, not lit
tile surprised at the sight; but the old lady
cnquired of her very kindly, whether she
had not come to fetch wine from the knights
cellarl' Yes, am replied the timid girl.
but have got no money Come with me-

for nothing; and better wine than your Ia
ther ever bought in his life They both
proceeded along an old deserted road, the OLD
lady enquiring very particularly, by tine
way, what the appearance OF things theh


was in Tlleda-who was alive, and who was
,lead' Once said she i was as young and


pretty as thou art, before ! was kidnapped


and carried under ground by the knights OF


rather night riders, who stole me away from
the very house that now belongs 10 thy IA
ther,-Short!y after this they mao selZed
tour vounp ladies' of those parts who were


often seen about here OIL their tour richly


canar;soned steeds.--They were entrapped


ami c,rr;ed off in open day BY these noun


tain knights. as they were Coming from


cbnrch At Kelbra. They made me. as


prew older, into the housckeeFer, and en-


trusted me with the keys of the cellar,


which YOU see still wear BY this time


thev had reached the cellar door, which the
old hon,e-keeper unlocked. 1t was spa
cious cellar. and on both sides it was we'll
| laid out with a row of watts and butts. Most
of them were quite nr more than half iu!l,
and broaching one of them with great deX-
terity, she took the little hrkin and filled it
to the brim. There said she, take that
to YOUR father, and whenever he may hap
pen to be giving a treat, you may come a.
gain; onl% see that you tell no one beslues
your father, where you have it from. And
moreover, take heed that you sell none OF 1t.
nor give it away, for in either case will 1t be


worth any thing at all. Ii any one venture

THE KNIGHTS CELLAR IN THE KYLE.


HAUSEN.
A GERMAN STORY.

he coffin is left at rest, and Immediately
the whole multitude join in the melancholy
chant. Some voices tremble with emotion,
and soon cease entirely, after All interval to
resume the strain:


Away, away--far above the sky,


mount on angel wings,


And the gale of Heaven rushes by


Bearing celestial harmony,


And joy on my spirit fiings.


Adieu to the world that held so dear,


Farewell to each tender tie;


Weep not weep not, for a brighter sphere


Shall soothe my soul and dspcl the tear


In the home prepared OH high.
fsee, I see the celestial gate,


And a glorious rest is nigh;


leave, leave but weary state,


Fora scene where endless delights await


In the home prepared on high.


Away, away-far above the sky,


mount on angel wings,


And the gale of heaven rushes by


Bearing celestial harmony,


And joy on my spirit fling.


On, what sound is here! The young,
and beautiful, the joyous uniting with the
aged christian in the death song, all stand
ing subduel and weeping in the open air a.
round the grave. There are eyes dmmed
now that have not wept before; there are
lofty spirits bowed which lately thought of
death with carelessness and contempt, and
a meek and hallowed resignation tempers
the aspiring mind to the lowly disposition of
the followers of Christ. may hope that
man. who witness this scene and share these
feelings which never lose the impression,
but by their grief for another's death may
be better prepared tor their own. The
hymn is over the coffin is in the ground,
and each gentle maid as she passes by drops
her rose bud into the grave, and looking
down, weeps atrcsh as she reads engraved
on the silver plate the name of her beloved
fricud-MARY MANDELL.

The step will be feeble, its ariness gone,
And the roses Of youth will be pallid and wan
And the brightness fade from the sunken eye,
And the graces of manhood will wither and die.
But there is a scene, as good men teach,
Where the chill ofmy bl,ghting blast never can


rcach,@
Where the virtues and graces that dwelt with


man,
In more perfect beauty shall bloom again
Where the winter of age shall forever be o'cT,
And the storm of death shall wther no more.


1st December, 1926

Mr. Brigham, the American missionary
to Suath America, gives the following de-
scription of the laderas, or awful precipice
in the Passes over the Andes. thro' which


he was obliged to SO in the journey from


Mendoza to Chill.


"Leaving our place of cncampment, we


travelled for tour hours along the banks of
the river, on gradually ascending, yet wide


and beautiful road But now we reached
the first iladeras, Of which / heard much,
dreaded some, and yet long wished to See


To conceive the nature OF these laderas, it
must be understood, that the road up this
mountain, is long, narrow, deep cut val
ley, down which descends a swift river.---
The road on the north side of the stream,
and generally the space between it and the
parallel ltlfty mountains,is ten or twelve rods


wide; sufficiently so as for good road even


for carriages. 1t occurs, however, in several
instances, that spur in this parallel noun


tain projects and extends to the very BRINK


of the river, leaving you the alternative ei-


ther to pass over its high snow capt summit,


or crawl alongthe precipice by the side ofthe


river, at the ordinary elevation OF the COM


mon road. The last course by the ladera


precipice is sometimes the only one where


the spur can possibly be passed. How this
4 fOau tllOUp lnG idtReTdS, Idthcl tiiio
path, was first formed, il is not easy to see.
! The precipce or slope of the mountain, to-


wards the river, though not perpendicular,


is nearly so, is at an angle OF Is If not ~


degrees with the horizon. The length of


the laderas is from twelve to thirty rods,


and the path along the sides from one to two
feet in width. Just sufficient tor the mule to
pass The mountain on tine right hand is


so close, that, sitting on the mule, you often
touch it with your knee. your hand, and can
sometimes with your head; and looking up,
its top is in the clouds But on the lett


hand, the precipicc below is the place OF
horror You look down a gulf of five, and
in one place seven hundred feet descent, at
the bottom of which rolls the fnrious Men.


loza, eight miles an hour, bearing at its top


trees, leaves, grass and mud, and in its bed,


stones and rocks continually rumbling, like


distant thunder. So steep is the descent,


that little stones jostled from the path, are


almost instantly in the river, and by one


stumble, one slip of the mule. he falls head


long, and none but He who made the noun


tains could save you. If there is place on


this rugged earth, which deserves to be
4 called sublime, it is that seen by him, who


passes the laderas, i'll the Andes OF South
i America.


But while pronounce the places descrin-
{ ed to be sublime, and even awful tc him
who bcholds them, must dissent from the


opinion Of those, who thnS there IS, with


proper caution, any serious danger in pass
ing them. What proves that there is not
is the fact, that no one, whom bave seen,
knows of any human life having been lost
, here, although this road has been travelled
; for more than two centuries and a halt
! Mules are often lost acre; not year passes
f in which several are not hurled down thi
gulf, and their cargoes lost. But this is ow
, ing to the fact, that they often carry boxes
or sacks, of such magnitude, as to strike a
gainst the mountain above the path, alle
force the poor animal hesdlong of the othsl


side, into the torrent below. That this mlgh
not occur with our mules and baggage, We
/ ordered iasos to be put around the nechSi "
s those which ',ad the large and valuable car
, goes, and that they should be led across .hs
: laderas. But this precaution cannot be takef
I where a troop of several hundred pass a'
+ is often done; consequently sometimes pl
e touching the upper bank, and sometimes p1
c the mules crowding each other, carsocs ar
: lost. 1t is but a short time since one wen
J. down the gulf with load OF seven thousant
/. dollars in Silver and gold. 1t were IN van
(: To Look for the lost articles here. as the rive

Mute, mute is all


O'er Beauty's fall;


Her praise resoends no more when man


tied i'll her pail.


The calm repose of sabbath morning
had settled upon my native village, when l
stood upon the hill that overlooksit. contcm-
plating the surrounding beauties. No unfit
ting sounds disturb the composure of tie
scene, for the notes of business and recrea
tion were hushet; the melody of the wild
birds and the hollow murmurs from the pine
grove, united with the unccasing dash ot a
distant cascade in hallowcd harmony, which
seemed to be the matin hymn Of Mature 20
her God. The quiet Of all things around
luled the stir of worldly feeling within, and
spread through my breast like eompostrr.
AS gazed upon the lovely prospect before
me,-the green hills sweeping around the
village and enclosing it in an ampitheatre,
the river glistening in the morning sun, and
the blue hills towering beyond with not a
| frewn upon the whole expanse OF azure SKY,
Il felt how beautiful is the earth. Musing
upon the Kindness of Heaven to my native
| land, to my friends and myself, spirit of
gratitude and devotion eXerted its soothing
influence and ftly tempered my feelings to
the sacredness of the day.-There are some
who look upon the charms of nature, with a
melancholy delight, and retire from the view
with minds saddcned and dark. The falling
| leaf is type of their own evanescence; au-
tumn will drive away the songsters of the
grove AS their own joys must be scattered;
and the storm will blight the scene where
all is sweet and flowery, as grief and dis
tress will shade their own bosoms. For how
many ages has the stream rolled on in its
beauty and mljesty, and how soon will i,
flow past their tomb as joyously as if they
had never been. On its banks the crowd
will hustle and toll and sport, while they arc
dust, and their names forgot. Thus they
turn sadly away from a view which if con
templated Alright, would awake far different
and holer feelings. How are they to be pit
led whose minds are thus chained to earth
who thus fear the grave Fair as the scenes
Of earth may be, dear and delightful as are
its lows, there are fairer and brighter scenes
beyond; the charms with which the Almigh-
ty has decorated this place of existence are
but faint display of his power and good
dcss. While gazing upon them, the heart
should expand with thanktulness and praise
that regions of superior spiendor and happi-
ness are prepared for man.


Far as my ken could stretch over that faii
scene, all up and down the banks of that
sparkling river, from the low tenement III the
field to the proud mansion Of the wealthy
there was sorrow that day. One who hae
been known and beloved by all, whose beau
ty and gentleness had endearcd her to ever,
bosom, was that day to be laid in the grave
Besides the usual solemnity which the fu
neral service spreads through country vii
lage, every indis sidual mourned persona
/, loss; it was like parting with IA relative. fo
each had regarded the deceased as some
thing lovely and inestimable that belonged
), to their community and was its ornamen
!, and pride. Each had daily for long pcrio'
inquired after her state, and many tea
had fallen ere she was removed forever,
her sufferings, her resignation and piet.
were affectionately recounted. Often a
lovers strayed abroad in the moonlight even
II ing. and exchanged their gentle words of en-
dearment, with loves own mild star midi.
;, beaming over them, would the discours
= turn to her who had been to them as sis
ter They dwclt upon her purity of charac
Iter, her utter forgetfulness Of self, her de

turned from what she had been in her mai
denly glee and bloom, to contemplate her
when her heart had been crushed, when her
fairest and fondest hopes were withered at
once, and stood like one between earth and
heaven waiting for wings to watt her to the
happier sphere. Then sorrowing tears and
sobs stole from the gentler being and sigh
expressed the grief of a manly bosom, and
each felt the bonds of mutual affection
drawn closer as they mourned together over
the wreck ofthc young, beautiful, and lately
happy creature who was unrepiningly, nay,
gladly approaching that event which has
such gloom for youthful hearts.


On the morning Of that sabbath, every bc-
som in the village was tempered with more
than usual solennity, and every prayer that
assembled came warmer from the heart.
Ihe meeting bell warned me to draw nigh
the House OF Gnd, and as went, on every
countenance marked the tnr of grief, a
calm expression OF sorrow which showed
that the spirit was indeed affected. At the
close OF the morning services. when our aged
pastor mentioned that funeral sermon
would be preached i'll the Afternoon, and n,-


medlately alter, the corpse be conveyed
from the meeting house to the grave, though


all previously knew that such was the ar
ransement, a deep hush pc.vadcd the house
few tears trickled silently, and when his


words were finished, breathing sound like
genera! sigh was heard, and each retired
with suJdued and saddencd feelings


| Never was our meeting house SO crowded
as on that afternoon, and all who came were
nourners. There was no confusion, fer
each arrived early to have last lock of ono
they loved; the coffin with the lid thrown
open rested in the broad aisle, and after a
glance at the still placid features, late all
6caming with fife aud joyousness, they re-
tired with softer tread and more halowed
feelings. AS the house became fuller tho
men silently resigned their seats and stood
in the aisles, aud many hard, worldly lace,
WAS shaded with Il raised hat te conceal that
soitcning of the teatures which all ragged
bosoins are ashamed to exhibit. Though
the number WAS immense, greater stiffness
never reigned, and when the audience rose
to pray, it was by one simultaneous move
mcDt without hustle and noise of seats
wlicn too often prevail. Before the PRAYER
was ended, many gentle frames had sunk
I! down upon the seat soVercome by weeping,
| and many naughty eye was shaded.


I Our ecnerab:e minister. his voice broken
with emotion, took tor his text a passage
! from beautiful chapter Of Iob-1ian COM
eth forth as q .fo,prr, and is CIT DORM; nc
/ teen also as a shuIo.c, and continneM not.
! The sermon was such as all ought to be-


calculated to make men better; but the
preacher felt his subject, and was therefore
eloquent, and he found that the feeling
which made tears stream over his iurrow-
ed cheeks was participated by all present.
Some few were overborne by the tide otfeel
ling and were compelled to withdraw, but
itt,


and fixed their eyes upon his fearful face,


wholly unconscious that the same marks of
sorrow rolled ever their own cheeks. At
Intervals a stihed sob was heard, and gentler


soul OF woman was entirely dissolved in


weeping. When the sermon was over, and


the low, solemn, oft repeated notes OF the


funeral anthem walled on the car, mourning


the supremacy of death, cold shudder


went through the house, and look OF dcs-


pairing widncss was OIL many features; but


when the strain swelled into the glorious


peal OF triumph that another angel was adj


ded to the skies, every heart was resigned,


and with returning confidence and hope ech-


oetl the sentiment, "Oh, grave, where is


thy victory =


The simple procession was soon on its


way. The hearse was in attendance, but


was not allowed to be used; a number OF


Young men who knew the deceased and low


ed her as a sister, took the bier upon their


shoulders, and occasionally relieving each


other, bore the respected bulthen all the


way to the grave. A few white roses part


lv withered, we're strewed as emblems OH
the pail. First after the coffin, came the


old minister supporting an aged woman,
the only person who was clothed in deep
, mourning. 1t was found that without any
. previous concert, all the maids of the vii
, lage, from the little girl of seven summers
to her who like the deceased had just bloom
, ed into womanhood, had arranged them
selves into pairs, with pale blossom at their
breasts, quietly placed themselves in the
procession Then followed long file Of
matrons, succeeded by the boys from the


sunday school, and these again followed by
I the various inhabitants OF the village.
| have looked on long professions honorine
, the remains of the soldier and statesman
the quaint attire Of masons, the reversed
arms and furled banners of the military, the
gorgeous hearse, and the string OF mourning
, coaches; but the mulfled drum. the low deatl
dirgc, the glitter, pomp and pageantry o
wealth and pride failed to make such deep
holy and lasting impressions as sunk into my
heart at the spontaneous and affecting re
r speet rendered to simple village maid-i
: was the tribute of our better feelings to dc
] parted excellence.


t The bier rests upon the ground; younl

Oh, what is Beauty's power
1t fourislies and dies;
Will the cold earth its silence break
To tell how soft, how smooth 4 check

Mute, mute is all


O'er Beauty's fall;
Her praise resoends no more when man

full articles.headline:
.ryTl TADrus' TR.MyaD.

REFLECTIONS ON THE MARRIED STATE.


BIZ a MmYied Man.
full articles.article:
The leading features in the character of
a good woman, are mildness, complaisance,
and equaninity of temper The man, II he
be a providcnt and worthy husband, is i'm
nersed IN Thousand cares. His mind is
agitated, his memory loaded, and his body
fatiguet,. He retircs from the hustle of the
world, chasrincd, perhaps, by disappoiht-
ment, angry at indolcnt or perhdous peo.
pie, and terrified lest his unavoidable con-
nexons with such people, should make him
appear periidious himself. Is this the time
for the wife Of his bosom, his dearest and
most intimate friend, to add to his vcXations,
to increase the fever of an oyerburthened
mind by contentious tongue, or discon-
tented brow? Business, in its most prosper
Gus state, is full of anxiety, labor and tur-
mol. o, how dear to the memory Ct man
is the wife who clothes her tace in smiles,
who uses gentle expressions, and who IN 4krs
her lap soft to receive and hush his Cares to
rest. There is not in nature SO fascinating
an object. as . faithful! tender and affections
ate wife.

sweeps every thing along its course, and one
can scarcely get to its waters with any Safe
ty, till it enters the Mendoza plains thirteen
miles below.


In passing the first ladera, we were great
ly alarmed for short time, by circum-
stance which grew out of carelessness.-
Not sending one forward on foot, as we
ought, to see if the way was clear, six of us
advanced SO far, that we could not return,
when we saw, entering the west end of the
ladera, drove of mules, which must soon
meet US. What was to be done For eli
ther party to return, was impossible; to pass
each other no less so. would almost have
sacrificed limb to have been free from the
danger which threatened. As good Provi-
dence ordained it, however, our guide recol-
lectetl that, in the centre of the ladera, then
out of sight, there was a small ravine. or
break in the mountain, where brook de-
scendetl, and where, if we could reach be-
fore the other loose mules met US, we could
probably halt in safety. We reached the
wished-for spot, and crowded our six mules
into a small excavation, which a cascade.
when the brook was high, had made, and
here waited till 800 mules and four men had
passed We then came out of our den,
passed the other part of the ladera, and SO
reached in safety, another wide and good
road.


Just before night we passed the second
ladera, called, Laderas de Ia .racas, the
worst Of them all, but which, with caution,
we passed in perfect safety,-Over this,
ventured to walk and let the mule follow,
but would not again. Ones head is liable
to swim, and then his feet to stumble,
whereas mules head, in such places, is al
WAYS clear, and his feet secure.


The sagacity Of this animal in travelling
over those rough and dangerous roads is tru-
ly remarkable. When he steps on a stone
which rolls or finds his feet likely to give
way, instead of springing to recover himself.
like the horse, he lifts his feet, and places
them again, with increased slowness and eau
tiun, until the danger is passed. When car
ryng baggage, he soon learns to keep at such
distance from loaded mules and other objects
which he may meet, as that his cargo sell
dom strikes any thing around him. In cross
ing these narrow laderas, | observed that
the older baggage mules, to avoid contact
with the mountains above, would walk all
most to the extreme lower edge of the path.
| This caution of course arises not from any
design to preserve the load in charge, but
to save themselves from the severe jar,
which every such contact gives them.
In the worst and most dangerous places
they are perfectly composed, and, if let a.
lone and suffered to pick their own way,
will carry you through them in safety, but,
as the peones say, "it is dangerous to force
one o. those animals, where he, on mature
delioeration, thinks it not best to CO."

THE FoRsAKEN.
full articles.article:
81 drcam'd dream that ] had flung a cham
OF roses around l.oye-I woke and found
had ciain'd Sorrow"


have caught the last wave Of his snow-whitc


plume!


How f,st to night closes the evening gloom--
lb,ve heard the last sound of his horsc's feet
On wndi once more the echo repeat!
; shoukl no, weep thus, if thou vert gone
Away 10 tic battle, as oft thou hast done;
Or il wept, my tears would be
But voiceess prisons for thee.
Thou vert wont TO palt--rny scarf on thine


arm.


Afy last kiss laid on thy lips like a charm
could play and believe that Thy maiden's pray'r
Would be wtl. thee il b@ttie. and guard thee


there.


But now thou a,t gone 10 The festival.
To the crowded city, the lighted hall:
In tho courtly beau,l's shining bower,
Little thou'lt think Of thine own wild flower.
Thou wilt Join in the midnight saraband,
With thy graceful smile and thy Whisper bland;
And to many another thou wilt be,
All thou once wert TO only me.
Ymirht haze known what would be my share
Silent suffering, and secret care:
Imght haze flown my wonan's part
faded cheek, and rifed heart.
Often Tread in the minstreltale
How bright eyes grow dim, and rcd lips pale;
Ofthe tears that wall the fond maiden's lot,
But loved thee, and all but my love forgot.
And must this be, oh, heart of mine!
Why art thou not too proud to pine!
Again will wrcathe my raven hair
With the wild rose flowers it was wont to wear.
Again will enter my r;l4her's hall;
Again be the gaycst and gladest of all:
Like the falcon, that soars at her highest bound,
Though her bosom bears its red dea.h-wound.
But what boots it to teach my heart task
So vain, as weeping behind mask;
Broken, with only ruins to hide,
Little it rocks of the show of pride.
viii a smile bring back to my lip its red,
Orthe azure light from my blue eyes fed,
Eflace from the faded brow and cheek
The tale that tells my heart must break.
No! I will away to my solitude,
And hang my head in my darkest moodi
Passing away with silent sigh,
Unknown, unwept, and thus will die!
FAREWELL FAREWELL have but one prayer,
That no thought may haunt thee ofrny despair;
Be nv memory to thee pleasant thing,
An odour that came and passed with thy spring.
Forget mel would not have thee know
of the youth and bloom thy falseness laid low;
That the green grass grows, the Expresses wave
And the deatl-stone lies OH thy once loves grave


l.. E. l..

THE ADVENT OF WINTER.
full articles.article:
THE ADVENT OF WINTER.


BY c. W. THOMPSON.
come, come from the icy seas,
Where the bleak winds blow and the salt waves


freeze,


Where the sun shines on thro' long days light
And at last gives place to a long-long night
Where the wild Aurora brilliantly plays,
Darling its beautiful lancc-like rays;
Where the white bear sits with his shaggy form,
And howls to the roar of the beating storm.
Where never is heard the voice of Spring,
And seldom the flap of the warber's wing
Where the fruits Of the Autumn are few and rare,
Aifatd to encounter the spirit OF air.
Where music is mute and song is dumb,
From regions Of polar ice come.
come, come---and when appear
VANISH the glories that deck the year
INT Inc verdurc Of Spring is scar and dead,
Inc flowers of summer are passed and fled
ne fruits Of autumn arc pale and wan-
uhc breath from me and their life is gone,
Nhen touch the wood with my wand again,
No-not one leaf shall there remain
nave no taste for their gaudy shine:
simple robe of white is mine,
Win glittering snow wreath round my brow,
Nay-'tis a tairer crown vow


man all the sparkling gems that are set
Ill the naughty monarch's coronet.
come in gloom, yet promise joy
ror bring to your homestead sweet employ.
lhe social hearth with its cheerful blaze,
Inc long nights that shelter from busting days
me family tryst and the holiday cheer,
,r Ihat enllyen the close of the fading year
,,, me touch ofthe harp and the sound oft lutte
"Ih voices that Nature n'er meant to be mute
n,i., nnn wit that wakes when it bathes in wine,
"im music and mirth and song are mine.
come, though ye do not call
"A, 1of he hlhe IS the fate that comes to all:
an9 ano the young may rejoice when youth is by,
anu 'aunt in their strength-that strength vii
rhe mo .ne spring tide of life is around them now
aus sns .s sas'ic step and the shining brow,
Y.s a thN ,ne auburn hair that curlingly flows
Y. .ae winter Of age will bring its SNOWY.

full articles.headline:
THE KNIGHTS CELLAR IN THE KYLE.


HAUSEN.
full articles.article:
There was poor but very honest, con-
tented, and merry kind of a man, in the vii
lage of rilleda, who happened to be giving
christening treat, for about the eighth
time to some OF his neighbours. DESTROYS
of showing all respect to the party OF chris
tening he set before them the best wine he
possessed. which being quick dispatched,
his guests seemed to be looking for little
more. Go them said the father to the eld-
est daughter, a young girl about sixteen
years old, 'go and bring us some better
wine from the cellar From what cellar.
father p enquired his daughter What cell
lar, child replied the father, merely IN
Jest; why, the great wine cellar belonging
to the Knights upon the kytf Hausen.'
With perfect simplicity the young maiden
took frkin in her hand and proceeded to-
wards the mountain. About middle way,
seated in an old deserted path leading down,
towards the spot, she found an aged house
keeper, dressed III singular quaint fashion.
with large bunch of keys hanging at her
side. The young woman paused, not lit
tile surprised at the sight; but the old lady
cnquired of her very kindly, whether she
had not come to fetch wine from the knights
cellarl' Yes, am replied the timid girl.
but have got no money Come with me-
SalN LIE oiu HpuoC-heSPSi, goa S'"' - -
for nothing; and better wine than your Ia
ther ever bought in his life They both
proceeded along an old deserted road, the OLD
lady enquiring very particularly, by tine
way, what the appearance OF things theh


was in Tlleda-who was alive, and who was
,lead' Once said she i was as young and


pretty as thou art, before ! was kidnapped


and carried under ground by the knights OF


rather night riders, who stole me away from
the very house that now belongs 10 thy IA
ther,-Short!y after this they mao selZed
tour vounp ladies' of those parts who were


often seen about here OIL their tour richly


canar;soned steeds.--They were entrapped


ami c,rr;ed off in open day BY these noun


tain knights. as they were Coming from


cbnrch At Kelbra. They made me. as


prew older, into the housckeeFer, and en-


trusted me with the keys of the cellar,


which YOU see still wear BY this time


thev had reached the cellar door, which the
old hon,e-keeper unlocked. 1t was spa
cious cellar. and on both sides it was we'll
| laid out with a row of watts and butts. Most
of them were quite nr more than half iu!l,
and broaching one of them with great deX-
terity, she took the little hrkin and filled it
to the brim. There said she, take that
to YOUR father, and whenever he may hap
pen to be giving a treat, you may come a.
gain; onl% see that you tell no one beslues
your father, where you have it from. And
moreover, take heed that you sell none OF 1t.
nor give it away, for in either case will 1t be


worth any thing at all. Ii any one venture
hither to obtain wine for sale, let him TIC


warned, his las. bread has been traSeu~-noN

he coffin is left at rest, and Immediately
the whole multitude join in the melancholy
chant. Some voices tremble with emotion,
and soon cease entirely, after All interval to
resume the strain:


Away, away--far above the sky,


mount on angel wings,


And the gale of Heaven rushes by


Bearing celestial harmony,


And joy on my spirit fiings.


Adieu to the world that held so dear,


Farewell to each tender tie;


Weep not weep not, for a brighter sphere


Shall soothe my soul and dspcl the tear


In the home prepared OH high.
fsee, I see the celestial gate,


And a glorious rest is nigh;


leave, leave but weary state,


Fora scene where endless delights await


In the home prepared on high.


Away, away-far above the sky,


mount on angel wings,


And the gale of heaven rushes by


Bearing celestial harmony,


And joy on my spirit fling.


On, what sound is here! The young,
and beautiful, the joyous uniting with the
aged christian in the death song, all stand
ing subduel and weeping in the open air a.
round the grave. There are eyes dmmed
now that have not wept before; there are
lofty spirits bowed which lately thought of
death with carelessness and contempt, and
a meek and hallowed resignation tempers
the aspiring mind to the lowly disposition of
the followers of Christ. may hope that
man. who witness this scene and share these
feelings which never lose the impression,
but by their grief for another's death may
be better prepared tor their own. The
hymn is over the coffin is in the ground,
and each gentle maid as she passes by drops
her rose bud into the grave, and looking
down, weeps atrcsh as she reads engraved
on the silver plate the name of her beloved
fricud-MARY MANDELL.

The step will be feeble, its ariness gone,
And the roses Of youth will be pallid and wan
And the brightness fade from the sunken eye,
And the graces of manhood will wither and die.
But there is a scene, as good men teach,
Where the chill ofmy bl,ghting blast never can


rcach,@
Where the virtues and graces that dwelt with


man,
In more perfect beauty shall bloom again
Where the winter of age shall forever be o'cT,
And the storm of death shall wther no more.


1st December, 1926

full articles.headline: PASSAGE OVER THE ANDES.
full articles.article:
Mr. Brigham, the American missionary
to Suath America, gives the following de-
scription of the laderas, or awful precipice
in the Passes over the Andes. thro' which


he was obliged to SO in the journey from


Mendoza to Chill.


"Leaving our place of cncampment, we


travelled for tour hours along the banks of
the river, on gradually ascending, yet wide


and beautiful road But now we reached
the first iladeras, Of which / heard much,
dreaded some, and yet long wished to See


To conceive the nature OF these laderas, it
must be understood, that the road up this
mountain, is long, narrow, deep cut val
ley, down which descends a swift river.---
The road on the north side of the stream,
and generally the space between it and the
parallel ltlfty mountains,is ten or twelve rods


wide; sufficiently so as for good road even


for carriages. 1t occurs, however, in several
instances, that spur in this parallel noun


tain projects and extends to the very BRINK


of the river, leaving you the alternative ei-


ther to pass over its high snow capt summit,


or crawl alongthe precipice by the side ofthe


river, at the ordinary elevation OF the COM


mon road. The last course by the ladera


precipice is sometimes the only one where


the spur can possibly be passed. How this
4 fOau tllOUp lnG idtReTdS, Idthcl tiiio
path, was first formed, il is not easy to see.
! The precipce or slope of the mountain, to-


wards the river, though not perpendicular,


is nearly so, is at an angle OF Is If not ~


degrees with the horizon. The length of


the laderas is from twelve to thirty rods,


and the path along the sides from one to two
feet in width. Just sufficient tor the mule to
pass The mountain on tine right hand is


so close, that, sitting on the mule, you often
touch it with your knee. your hand, and can
sometimes with your head; and looking up,
its top is in the clouds But on the lett


hand, the precipicc below is the place OF
horror You look down a gulf of five, and
in one place seven hundred feet descent, at
the bottom of which rolls the fnrious Men.


loza, eight miles an hour, bearing at its top


trees, leaves, grass and mud, and in its bed,


stones and rocks continually rumbling, like


distant thunder. So steep is the descent,


that little stones jostled from the path, are


almost instantly in the river, and by one


stumble, one slip of the mule. he falls head


long, and none but He who made the noun


tains could save you. If there is place on


this rugged earth, which deserves to be
4 called sublime, it is that seen by him, who


passes the laderas, i'll the Andes OF South
i America.


But while pronounce the places descrin-
{ ed to be sublime, and even awful tc him
who bcholds them, must dissent from the


opinion Of those, who thnS there IS, with


proper caution, any serious danger in pass
ing them. What proves that there is not
is the fact, that no one, whom bave seen,
knows of any human life having been lost
, here, although this road has been travelled
; for more than two centuries and a halt
! Mules are often lost acre; not year passes
f in which several are not hurled down thi
gulf, and their cargoes lost. But this is ow
, ing to the fact, that they often carry boxes
or sacks, of such magnitude, as to strike a
gainst the mountain above the path, alle
force the poor animal hesdlong of the othsl


side, into the torrent below. That this mlgh
not occur with our mules and baggage, We
/ ordered iasos to be put around the nechSi "
s those which ',ad the large and valuable car
, goes, and that they should be led across .hs
: laderas. But this precaution cannot be takef
I where a troop of several hundred pass a'
+ is often done; consequently sometimes pl
e touching the upper bank, and sometimes p1
c the mules crowding each other, carsocs ar
: lost. 1t is but a short time since one wen
J. down the gulf with load OF seven thousant
/. dollars in Silver and gold. 1t were IN van
(: To Look for the lost articles here. as the rive

Beneath its surface lies


Mute, mute is all


O'er Beauty's fall;


Her praise resoends no more when man


tied i'll her pail.


The calm repose of sabbath morning
had settled upon my native village, when l
stood upon the hill that overlooksit. contcm-
plating the surrounding beauties. No unfit
ting sounds disturb the composure of tie
scene, for the notes of business and recrea
tion were hushet; the melody of the wild
birds and the hollow murmurs from the pine
grove, united with the unccasing dash ot a
distant cascade in hallowcd harmony, which
seemed to be the matin hymn Of Mature 20
her God. The quiet Of all things around
luled the stir of worldly feeling within, and
spread through my breast like eompostrr.
AS gazed upon the lovely prospect before
me,-the green hills sweeping around the
village and enclosing it in an ampitheatre,
the river glistening in the morning sun, and
the blue hills towering beyond with not a
| frewn upon the whole expanse OF azure SKY,
Il felt how beautiful is the earth. Musing
upon the Kindness of Heaven to my native
| land, to my friends and myself, spirit of
gratitude and devotion eXerted its soothing
influence and ftly tempered my feelings to
the sacredness of the day.-There are some
who look upon the charms of nature, with a
melancholy delight, and retire from the view
with minds saddcned and dark. The falling
| leaf is type of their own evanescence; au-
tumn will drive away the songsters of the
grove AS their own joys must be scattered;
and the storm will blight the scene where
all is sweet and flowery, as grief and dis
tress will shade their own bosoms. For how
many ages has the stream rolled on in its
beauty and mljesty, and how soon will i,
flow past their tomb as joyously as if they
had never been. On its banks the crowd
will hustle and toll and sport, while they arc
dust, and their names forgot. Thus they
turn sadly away from a view which if con
templated Alright, would awake far different
and holer feelings. How are they to be pit
led whose minds are thus chained to earth
who thus fear the grave Fair as the scenes
Of earth may be, dear and delightful as are
its lows, there are fairer and brighter scenes
beyond; the charms with which the Almigh-
ty has decorated this place of existence are
but faint display of his power and good
dcss. While gazing upon them, the heart
should expand with thanktulness and praise
that regions of superior spiendor and happi-
ness are prepared for man.


Far as my ken could stretch over that faii
scene, all up and down the banks of that
sparkling river, from the low tenement III the
field to the proud mansion Of the wealthy
there was sorrow that day. One who hae
been known and beloved by all, whose beau
ty and gentleness had endearcd her to ever,
bosom, was that day to be laid in the grave
Besides the usual solemnity which the fu
neral service spreads through country vii
lage, every indis sidual mourned persona
/, loss; it was like parting with IA relative. fo
each had regarded the deceased as some
thing lovely and inestimable that belonged
), to their community and was its ornamen
!, and pride. Each had daily for long pcrio'
inquired after her state, and many tea
had fallen ere she was removed forever,
her sufferings, her resignation and piet.
were affectionately recounted. Often a
lovers strayed abroad in the moonlight even
II ing. and exchanged their gentle words of en-
dearment, with loves own mild star midi.
;, beaming over them, would the discours
= turn to her who had been to them as sis
ter They dwclt upon her purity of charac
Iter, her utter forgetfulness Of self, her de

full articles.headline: 5ANUARX IL, 1927
full articles.article:
turned from what she had been in her mai
denly glee and bloom, to contemplate her
when her heart had been crushed, when her
fairest and fondest hopes were withered at
once, and stood like one between earth and
heaven waiting for wings to watt her to the
happier sphere. Then sorrowing tears and
sobs stole from the gentler being and sigh
expressed the grief of a manly bosom, and
each felt the bonds of mutual affection
drawn closer as they mourned together over
the wreck ofthc young, beautiful, and lately
happy creature who was unrepiningly, nay,
gladly approaching that event which has
such gloom for youthful hearts.


On the morning Of that sabbath, every bc-
som in the village was tempered with more
than usual solennity, and every prayer that
assembled came warmer from the heart.
Ihe meeting bell warned me to draw nigh
the House OF Gnd, and as went, on every
countenance marked the tnr of grief, a
calm expression OF sorrow which showed
that the spirit was indeed affected. At the
close OF the morning services. when our aged
pastor mentioned that funeral sermon
would be preached i'll the Afternoon, and n,-


medlately alter, the corpse be conveyed
from the meeting house to the grave, though


all previously knew that such was the ar
ransement, a deep hush pc.vadcd the house
few tears trickled silently, and when his


words were finished, breathing sound like
genera! sigh was heard, and each retired
with suJdued and saddencd feelings


| Never was our meeting house SO crowded
as on that afternoon, and all who came were
nourners. There was no confusion, fer
each arrived early to have last lock of ono
they loved; the coffin with the lid thrown
open rested in the broad aisle, and after a
glance at the still placid features, late all
6caming with fife aud joyousness, they re-
tired with softer tread and more halowed
feelings. AS the house became fuller tho
men silently resigned their seats and stood
in the aisles, aud many hard, worldly lace,
WAS shaded with Il raised hat te conceal that
soitcning of the teatures which all ragged
bosoins are ashamed to exhibit. Though
the number WAS immense, greater stiffness
never reigned, and when the audience rose
to pray, it was by one simultaneous move
mcDt without hustle and noise of seats
wlicn too often prevail. Before the PRAYER
was ended, many gentle frames had sunk
I! down upon the seat soVercome by weeping,
| and many naughty eye was shaded.


I Our ecnerab:e minister. his voice broken
with emotion, took tor his text a passage
! from beautiful chapter Of Iob-1ian COM
eth forth as q .fo,prr, and is CIT DORM; nc
/ teen also as a shuIo.c, and continneM not.
! The sermon was such as all ought to be-


calculated to make men better; but the
preacher felt his subject, and was therefore
eloquent, and he found that the feeling
which made tears stream over his iurrow-
ed cheeks was participated by all present.
Some few were overborne by the tide otfeel
ling and were compelled to withdraw, but
itt,


and fixed their eyes upon his fearful face,


wholly unconscious that the same marks of
sorrow rolled ever their own cheeks. At
Intervals a stihed sob was heard, and gentler


soul OF woman was entirely dissolved in


weeping. When the sermon was over, and


the low, solemn, oft repeated notes OF the


funeral anthem walled on the car, mourning


the supremacy of death, cold shudder


went through the house, and look OF dcs-


pairing widncss was OIL many features; but


when the strain swelled into the glorious


peal OF triumph that another angel was adj


ded to the skies, every heart was resigned,


and with returning confidence and hope ech-


oetl the sentiment, "Oh, grave, where is


thy victory =


The simple procession was soon on its


way. The hearse was in attendance, but


was not allowed to be used; a number OF


Young men who knew the deceased and low


ed her as a sister, took the bier upon their


shoulders, and occasionally relieving each


other, bore the respected bulthen all the


way to the grave. A few white roses part


lv withered, we're strewed as emblems OH
the pail. First after the coffin, came the


old minister supporting an aged woman,
the only person who was clothed in deep
, mourning. 1t was found that without any
. previous concert, all the maids of the vii
, lage, from the little girl of seven summers
to her who like the deceased had just bloom
, ed into womanhood, had arranged them
selves into pairs, with pale blossom at their
breasts, quietly placed themselves in the
procession Then followed long file Of
matrons, succeeded by the boys from the


sunday school, and these again followed by
I the various inhabitants OF the village.
| have looked on long professions honorine
, the remains of the soldier and statesman
the quaint attire Of masons, the reversed
arms and furled banners of the military, the
gorgeous hearse, and the string OF mourning
, coaches; but the mulfled drum. the low deatl
dirgc, the glitter, pomp and pageantry o
wealth and pride failed to make such deep
holy and lasting impressions as sunk into my
heart at the spontaneous and affecting re
r speet rendered to simple village maid-i
: was the tribute of our better feelings to dc
] parted excellence.
